results.title: Children and sports (TEFC)
results.brief_description: James Michener surveys the work of the young athlete, to discover how sports activities effect young children. He takes a close look at both individual and team sports, talks with parents, coaches, physicians, and today’s young superstars and weighs the pros and cons of winning verses learning.
results.description: James Michener surveys the work of the young athlete, to discover how sports activities effect young children. results.title: Children and sports
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “James Michener’s World”.
Narrator, James Michener takes a close look at individual and team sports in the context of children’s involvement. He shows how children’s sport reflects society’s emphasis on achievement. Speaking with parents, coaches, physicians and athletes, Michener weighs the pros and cons of winning vs learning to meet challenges; healthy exercise vs exposure to injury.

results.title: Children and abuse
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “PGR Series”.
There are four different categories of child abuse: Neglect, Emotional Abuse, Physical Abuse and Sexual Abuse. Through parents relating personal stories of their children and their experiences with child abuse P.G.R discusses the ease of damage to young children through any of the defined forms of abuse. Ways to create a positive emotional environment for the child, how to handle potential child abuse situations, and the value of “special time” are all discussed with parents.

results.title: Children (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Part two of the series, “The Family of Man” which sets out to compare family life in five different locations around the world. This programme shows the relationship between mothers and children, paternal influence and the use of mother substitutes, education and the preparation of children for adult life in traditional and modern settings in 1970.

results.title: Children's world of travel
results.creator_credit: Japan. Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Shin Riken Motion Pictures
results.brief_description: Children have many dreams and there is a common dream the whole world over - travel. In this film, the dreams of Japanese children come true - in the realm of modern Japanese transport, with examples of the fast gleaming monorail, cable cars and other unusual systems in use in Japan today.

results.title: Children's value judgements (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: David Seligman, Open University and BBC-TV
results.brief_description: Explains the four basic categories (intuitive, heteronomous, expedient, and altruistic) into which the cognitive styles used in making moral judgements are divided. Children are interviewed and their responses are labelled with one of these categories. Includes discussion of the implications of the postulated categories. A second level course in Educational Studies introduced by Norman Williams.

results.title: Children's thought and language
results.creator_credit: Michael Forlong Productions and Stefan Sargent Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Looking at Research”.
The film outlines a project sponsored by the Social Science Research Council to study childhood development of intelligence and to discover how much children understand.

results.title: Children's Theatre
results.creator_credit: Lilias Fraser, John Morris, Frank Bagnall and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Children at the Studio Theatre in Adelaide study painting, music and speech as part of their training in ballet. This is a Children’s Theatre for children and by children. Classes and rehearsals, planning and teaching precede the performance of an Australian ballet, telling the story of an Australian aboriginal legend.

results.title: Children's tapes
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, black and white and audio
results.brief_description: Children’s Tapes is a classic early video work, a seminal investigation that translates the aesthetics of minimalism, performance, perception and real time into the vernacular of the everyday. With ingenuity and wit, Fox constructs phenomenological dramas from the science of the quotidian. Suspense and surprise suffuse a series of anecdotal episodes that demonstrate basic physical phenomena. Fox builds dramatic tension and mystery with an extreme economy of means, focusing a stationary black-and-white camera on ordinary household objects. With the camera close to his still-life subjects, Fox constructs a series of elementary experiments that illustrate fundamental principles of physical science: A piece of fruit is placed under a tin lid held up by a single match, as an unsuspecting fly approaches the bait; a spoon, balanced on a fork, holds a piece of ice until the melting water topples it; a candle in a pan of water is extinguished when a pot is placed over it. The intimate scale, magnified view, and suspenseful unfolding of minute events in real time all serve to intensify the viewers’ perceptions and expectations in these engaging mini-narratives.
